body_html:
We'd have to see more of your code, or better yet a design proposal for how you want to implement the algorithm in tf. Your options for avoiding multiple session run calls include generating q and h in tf directly, out using py_func.
…
On Thu, Oct 26, 2017, 8:21 PM mushroom1116 ***@***.***> wrote: I'm trying to implementing the main idea of SparseCNN described in https://arxiv.org/pdf/1505.02890.pdf (page5) and encountered some problems. Q and H of each layer are different. In order to get the value of Q and H_out, I have to use sess.run() and it may cut the connection of gradient variables. I wonder if there are some bottlenecks in implementing SparseCNN using tensorflow API. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. On Thu, Oct 26, 2017, 8:21 PM mushroom1116 ***@***.***> wrote:
 I'm trying to implementing the main idea of SparseCNN described in
 https://arxiv.org/pdf/1505.02890.pdf (page5) and encountered some
 problems. Q and H of each layer are different. In order to get the value of
 Q and H_out, I have to use sess.run() and it may cut the connection of
 gradient variables.

 I wonder if there are some bottlenecks in implementing SparseCNN using
 tensorflow API.

 —

body:
We'd have to see more of your code, or better yet a design proposal for how
you want to implement the algorithm in tf.  Your options for avoiding
multiple session run calls include generating q and h in tf directly, out
using py_func.

On Thu, Oct 26, 2017, 8:21 PM mushroom1116 <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I'm trying to implementing the main idea of SparseCNN described in
> https://arxiv.org/pdf/1505.02890.pdf (page5) and encountered some
> problems. Q and H of each layer are different. In order to get the value of
> Q and H_out, I have to use sess.run() and it may cut the connection of
> gradient variables.
>
> I wonder if there are some bottlenecks in implementing SparseCNN using
> tensorflow API.
>
> —
